pullRequest.body:
add the structure `PreInnerProductSpace`, which does not assume `definite` for the inner product, with a proof of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality using the discriminant.

Motivation: Such structures arise very often in applications, and by quotienting the kernel one obtains `InnerProductSpace.Core`.

I duplicated most of the proofs from the namespace `InnerProductSpace.Core` and put them under the namespace `PreInnerProductSpace` . Is there a better way?

nodes.body:
### PR summary [5f93724fb7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14024/commits/5f93724fb770def9629e4fcb37d6ebf917f5b2b4)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Basic | 1470 | 1471 | +1 (+0.07%) |
| Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.PosDef | 1679 | 1680 | +1 (+0.06%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
There are 247 files with changed transitive imports: this is too many to display!

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ PreInnerProductSpace.Core`
`+ PreInnerProductSpace.toCore`
`+ cauchy_schwarz_aux'`
`+ inner_self_of_eq_zero`
`+ inner_smul_ofReal_left`
`+ inner_smul_ofReal_right`
`+ instance (ùïú : Type*) (F : Type*) [RCLike ùïú] [AddCommGroup F]`
`+ instance : InnerProductSpace ‚Ñù ‚ÑÇ := InnerProductSpace.complexToReal`
`+ ne_zero_of_inner_self_ne_zero`
`+ normSq_eq_zero_of_eq_zero`
`+ re_inner_smul_ofReal_smul_self`
`+ toPreInner'`
`+ toSeminormedAddCommGroup`
`+ toSeminormedSpace`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Well, you should remove the inner product versions for these that are strictly more general, as a first step.

@ADedecker do you have thoughts about this preinner product stuff before we get into the weeds of review?

I'm sorry I have absolutely no time to help reviewing this, I'm currently buried under PHD-funding paperwork and the related stress... But I did think about this some time ago, so here are my thoughts.

I strongly think the correct approach for the general theory is simply to assume only `SeminormedAddCommGroup E` in the definition of `InnerProductSpace` and in all the lemmas that work without definiteness : that way there is only one definition, and the choice to impose definiteness or not is obtained by choosing between `SeminormedAddCommGroup` and `NormedAddCommGroup`.

Of course this trick doesn't work for the "Core" version since it doesn't come with a norm. I am not so sure that it's the correct approach, but I would still say to just remove the definiteness from the definition, and add a `InnerProductSpace.normedAddCommGroupOfDefinite` constructor that also asks for a separate proof of definiteness. But please check it won't be too much of a hassle to use before going down that road.

Anyway, thanks for working on this!

@j-loreaux @ADedecker I see, I thought this would be a small PR, but instead there seems to be much to do! I probably need some time to do anything reasonable. Meanwhile, if you have comments on how things should be organized, please do so.

I completely agree with Anatole here. I had forgotten we separated out the `NormedAddCommGroup` so that it is a parameter instead of having `InnerProductSpace` extend it. So, the sensible thing to do as a first pass on this PR is the following: Replace `NormedAddCommGroup` with `SeminormedAddCommGroup` in the definition of `InnerProductSpace`. See what breaks, then in those places that it breaks, check that definiteness is required, and in those situations add a `NormedAddCommGroup` assumption (without overlapping the `Seminormed` one). Does this make sense @yoh-tanimoto ?

I tried, and the first issue is that, since I remove `definite` from `Core`, things break not with `NormedAddCommGroup` but when `definite` is used. What should I do with theorems using `definite`?  @j-loreaux

You should have two `.Core` things, one with definiteness and one with semi definiteness. On one you get a `NormedAddCommGroup` instance, and on the other you get a `SeminormedAddCommGroup` instance. It shouldn't be too big a deal because these should almost never be used anyway since you don't get good defeqs.for the norm.

I made two `.Core`s. Now the problem is where I want to prove theorems for `cd : InnerProductSpace.Core ùïú F`, but the local notation `‚ü™x, y‚ü´` is given for `c : PreInnerProductSpace.Core ùïú F`. How can I update the notation?

You can just close the scope for the existing local notation (this might mean moving it into a `section`), and write a new local notation. However, what probably makes the most sense is to separate out the stuff involving `InnerProductSpace.Core` into its own `section` instead of having them intermingled.

I am sorry for my late commits.
@j-loreaux I just accepted your suggestions, thank you very much for the simplifications, I need to learn these tactics!
@j-loreaux done!

Can you please merge master, then wait for CI to finish? After that, assuming CI is successful, you're welcome to merge.

bors d+

:v: yoh-tanimoto can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10276590561/job/28437234454)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10276590561/job/28437234300)
These are the last corrections. Ping me when you're finished and I'll merge.
Thanks again for taking this on. There's still room for improvement, but it's starting to look nice.
From my perspective, I think this is almost finished.
These are the last corrections. Ping me when you're finished and I'll merge.

Can you explain why you want to have two different classes instead of just one named `InnerProductSpace` but only assuming `[RCLike ùïú] [SeminormedAddCommGroup E]`? Then, depending on whether you want to have a norm or a seminorm, you would assume `[SeminormedAddCommGroup E]` or `[NormedAddCommGroup E]`, but use the same class `InnerProductSpace ùïú E`.

sorry, I misunderstood the discussion above. As it was suggested to add `InnerProductSpace.Core` and `PreInnerProductSpace.Core`, I thought it would apply to the class `Pre/InnerProductSpace` as well. I removerd `PreInnerProductSpace`.

The theorems are split in sections without and with `[NormedAddCommGroup E]`. I wonder whether this is the best way.

now for `InnerProductSpace.ofMatrix` in `Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Matrix.PosDef`, I had to weaken the definition (it is `InnerProductSpace` only with `SeminormedAddCommGroup`, not `NormedAddCommGroup`. Is this fine?
What you've done there is correct.
I see no reason we need to rename this. We don't have a separate name for `‚Äñ¬∑‚Äñ` in the cases of norms/seminorms.
ok, I restore the name and remove the duplicate definition.
Again, I don't think this should get renamed.
done.

I don't think you need to reinvent this. In fact, I think `cd.normSq` (with the revert to the naming I specified in an earlier comment) should Just Work‚Ñ¢ since `InnerProductSpace.Core` extends `PreInnerProductSpace.Core`. So adjusting the `local notation` command below should be all that's necessary.
done (I restored `normSq` above and removed this).
Similarly, I think you don't need a new definition. You should just be able to make the `PreInnerProductSpace.Core.toNorm` a local instance.
done.
Unless I missed something `ùïú` is now explicit here. Can we change it back for consistency?
sorry that I missed this, yes.
This `Pre` prefix in section names is just confusing. I know what you mean because of the context of this PR, but anyone else looking at this later is just going to ask: "what's a `PreSubmodule`?"
I see, I just thought that the same section title for different assumptions isn't good. I change to `XXX_Seminormed`, is this better?
same comment
ditto
ditto
ditto
Why do we need this import now but we didn't before?
I changed the proof of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality from the previous one (using `definite`) to the current one, so I needed the traditional argument involving discriminant.
I have a feeling there's a much easier-to-formalize proof here, but I don't have time at the moment. I'll come back to it.
OK, I leave this as is for now.

I've tried to make this proof a bit more formalization friendly by using some handy automation. The key tools to make this simpler were: `field_simp`, `convert`, `ring` and `positivity`. `suffices` is also nice for restructuring proofs, and `obtain` is just handy all around.
```suggestion
  suffices discrim (normSqF x) (2 * ‚Äñ‚ü™x, y‚ü´_ùïú‚Äñ) (normSqF y) ‚â§ 0 by
    rw [norm_inner_symm y x]
    rw [discrim, normSq, normSq, sq] at this
    linarith
  refine discrim_le_zero fun t ‚Ü¶ ?_
  by_cases hzero : ‚ü™x, y‚ü´ = 0
  ¬∑ simp only [mul_assoc, ‚Üê sq, hzero, norm_zero, mul_zero, zero_mul, add_zero, ge_iff_le]
    obtain ‚ü®hx, hy‚ü© : (0 ‚â§ normSqF x ‚àß 0 ‚â§ normSqF y) := ‚ü®inner_self_nonneg, inner_self_nonneg‚ü©
    positivity
  ¬∑ have hzero' : ‚Äñ‚ü™x, y‚ü´‚Äñ ‚â† 0 := norm_ne_zero_iff.2 hzero
    convert cauchy_schwarz_aux' (ùïú := ùïú) (‚ü™x, y‚ü´ ‚Ä¢ x) y (t / ‚Äñ‚ü™x, y‚ü´‚Äñ) using 3
    ¬∑ field_simp
      rw [‚Üê sq, normSq, normSq, inner_smul_right, inner_smul_left, ‚Üê mul_assoc _ _ ‚ü™x, x‚ü´,
        mul_conj, ‚Üê ofReal_pow]
      simp [- ofReal_pow, mul_re]
      ring
    ¬∑ field_simp
      rw [inner_smul_left, mul_comm _ ‚ü™x, y‚ü´_ùïú, mul_conj, ‚Üê ofReal_pow, ofReal_re]
      ring
```

Almost the original proof works, and your indentation has issues:
```suggestion
  rintro rfl
  exact inner_zero_left _
```

:golf:
```suggestion
  rintro rfl
  simp [normSq, inner_self_of_eq_zero]
```

This is just the contrapositive of the existing result, which we can obtain with `mt` (modus tollens)
```suggestion
theorem ne_zero_of_inner_self_ne_zero {x : F} : ‚ü™x, x‚ü´ ‚â† 0 ‚Üí x ‚â† 0 :=
  mt inner_self_of_eq_zero
```

I think these lemmas are slightly misnamed, and if you prove them in a slightly different order then it's easier:
```suggestion
theorem inner_smul_ofReal_left (x y : F) {t : ‚Ñù} : ‚ü™(t : ùïú) ‚Ä¢ x, y‚ü´ = ‚ü™x, y‚ü´  * t := by
  rw [inner_smul_left, conj_ofReal, mul_comm]

theorem inner_smul_ofReal_right (x y : F) {t : ‚Ñù} : ‚ü™x, (t : ùïú) ‚Ä¢ y‚ü´ = ‚ü™x, y‚ü´  * t := by
  rw [inner_smul_right, mul_comm]

theorem re_inner_smul_ofReal_smul_self (x : F) {t : ‚Ñù} :
    re ‚ü™(t : ùïú) ‚Ä¢ x, (t : ùïú) ‚Ä¢ x‚ü´ = normSqF x * t * t := by
  apply ofReal_injective (K := ùïú)
  simp [inner_self_ofReal_re, inner_smul_ofReal_left, inner_smul_ofReal_right, normSq]

```

```suggestion
  ‚ü®cd.definite _, inner_self_of_eq_zero‚ü©
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Basic): add PreInnerProductSpace
